Philosophy: "In rugby, it pays to be forceful, fast and aggressive." (paralympic.ca, 26 Apr 2012)
Award: He was named Best 1.5 Class Player at the 2016 Canadian Championships in Montreal, Quebec, and the 2010 World Championships in Vancouver, BC, Canada. (paralympic.ca, 01 Sep 2016; sirc.ca, 30 May 2016)
Injuries: In February 2017 he fractured his pelvis and suffered lacerations to the liver after being struck by a car in Phoenix, AZ, United States of America. It was nine months until he played again. (parasportsquebec.com, 30 Mar 2020, 08 Mar 2017)

name: SIMION Bobi
Debut: 2003 for Romania, in Ostrava, Czech Republic (Athlete, 21 May 2016)
Ambition: To win a medal at the Paralympic Games. (paralimpicromania.ro, 22 Sep 2019)
Hero: Spanish tennis player Rafael Nadal. (Athlete, 21 May 2016)
Philosophy: "If you don't fight, it means you do not believe in yourself." (Athlete, 21 May 2016)

name: SIMMONDS Eleanor
Debut: 2006 for Great Britain, World Championships in Durban, South Africa (telegraph.co.uk, 05 Aug 2013)
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. She hopes to work as a teacher after retiring from the sport. (bbc.co.uk, 27 Jun 2017; palatinate.org.uk, 06 Mar 2020)
Hero: US tennis player Serena Williams, British heptathlete Jessica Ennis-Hill, British Para swimmer Nyree Kindred [nee Lewis]. (palatinate.org.uk, 06 Mar 2020)
Philosophy: "Work hard and believe in yourself." (swimming.org, 23 Sep 2013)
Award: In January 2018 she received an honorary degree from Swansea University in Wales. (swimswam.com, 22 Jan 2018)
Injuries: At age 12 she had an operation to insert four metal plates into her legs. The plates were used to straighten her limbs. (dailystar.co.uk, 05 Sep 2012)

name: SIMPLICIO da SILVA Thalita Vitoria
Philosophy: "People should never give up on their dreams." (unp.br, 17 Oct 2019)
Award: She was one of 14 athletes honoured by the government of Rio Grande do Norte state in Brazil in recognition of their performances at the 2016 Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. (blogdedaltroemerenciano.com.br, 21 Sep 2016)

name: SIMPSON Matt
Ambition: To win gold at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (teamusa.org, 07 Jul 2021)
Philosophy: "As a person with a disability, I'm keenly aware of the fact that my greatest asset is my mind. Many times, I'm at a disadvantage. I'm blind, and I deal with various limitations. But education is the easiest way to maximise my advantages." (reuters.com, 23 Jul 2021)

name: SIMRAN
Ambition: To win gold at the Paralympic Games. (Dietitian Shreya YouTube channel, 05 Feb 2020)
Award: She was named Female Para Athlete of the Year for 2020 at the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce & Industry [FICCI] Turf 2020 India Sports Awards. (aroundtherings.com, 09 Dec 2020)

name: SIMS Natalie
Hero: US gymnast Simone Biles. (wiacsports.com, 02 Jun 2020)
Philosophy: "Working toward a goal makes me want to practise and try harder." (ywcampls.org, 04 Aug 2014)

name: SINGER Florian
Debut: 2017 for Germany (Athlete, 22 Aug 2021)
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (teamdeutschland-paralympics.de, 15 Jun 2021)

name: SINGH Deepender
Debut: 2017 for India (indianshooting.com, 09 Nov 2017)
Ambition: To win gold at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (jagran.com, 13 Nov 2017)

name: SINGH Harvinder
Philosophy: "Work hard so silently that your success makes all the noise." [Hindi proverb]. (paralympic.org, 23 May 2020)

name: SINGPIROM Comsan
Ambition: To win a gold medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (siamsport.co.th, 11 Jun 2019)

name: SINOVCIC Dino
Debut: 2005 for Croatia (Athlete, 12 Jul 2015)
Ambition: To win a gold medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (tportal.hr, 12 Sep 2019; telegram.hr, 04 May 2020)
Philosophy: "Absolutely everything in life can be achieved. It is only necessary to believe, to be persistent and to overcome the first obstacles." (dalmatinskiportal.hr, 02 Dec 2018)
Award: He received the 2019 Para Athlete the Year Award from the Croatian Paralympic Committee. (slobodnadalmacija.hr, 30 Jan 2020)
Injuries: He suffered from tendinitis in his shoulder between 2011 and 2014. (Athlete, 07 Sep 2016)

name: SISCAR MESEGUER Enrique
Philosophy: "Success is not the victory in itself, but all what you have fought to win." [Spanish tennis player Rafael Nadal]. (kikesiscar.com, 08 Jun 2021)
Award: In 2018 he was named Best Para Athlete of the Year of the Murcia region in Spain. (laverdad.es, 21 Aug 2021)

name: SITU Ntombizanele
Debut: 1996 for South Africa, World Championships in Great Britain (Athlete, 22 Oct 2015)
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (uct.ac.za, 08 Aug 2019; Team South Africa Instagram profile, 12 Sep 2020)
Hero: South African Para athlete Fanie Lombaard, South African middle-distance runner Caster Semenya. (sport.iafrica.com, 05 Sep 2012; Athlete, 26 Jan 2011)
Philosophy: "Keep going, follow your dreams and never give up." (sport.iafrica.com, 05 Sep 2012)
Award: In 2019 she received the Chief Director Merit Award at the Maties Sport Awards in Stellenbosch, South Africa. (Monster Javelin Coaching Facebook page, 18 Oct 2019)
Injuries: In early 2019 she sustained a shoulder injury. (Monster Javelin Coaching Facebook page, 01 Jul 2019)

name: SKALIUKH Alexander
Debut: 2011 for Russia, European Championships in Berlin, Germany (Athlete, 06 Apr 2015)
Ambition: To win gold at the Paralympic Games. (Athlete, 12 Mar 2021)
Award: He has received the title of Honoured Master of Sport in the Russian Federation. (paraswim.ru, 05 Mar 2021)

name: SKARSTEIN Birgit Lovise Roekkum
Debut: 2013 for Norway (worldrowing.com, 15 Sep 2015)
Ambition: To win a medal in rowing at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo, and compete in cross-country skiing at the 2022 Paralympic Winter Games in Beijing. (dagbladet.no, 05 Dec 2018)
Hero: Norwegian cross-country skier Marit Bjorgen. (Athlete, 26 Feb 2018)
Philosophy: "It'll work out." (Athlete, 26 Feb 2018)
Award: She was named Female Para Athlete of the Year at the 2019 Norway Sports Gala. She also received the Honorary Prize of Egeberg, which recognises Norwegian athletes who excel in more than one sport. (aftenposten.no, 25 May 2019; innherred.no, 05 Jan 2019)
Injuries: In January 2020 she sustained a torn stomach muscle and a stress fracture in her back. (vg.no, 07 Feb 2020)

name: SKELHON Matt
Ambition: To win a gold medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (Anything but Footy podcast, 14 Jan 2021)
Award: He was named the 2014 Sportsman of the Year by the Peterborough Telegraph newspaper in England. (peterboroughtoday.co.uk, 30 Jan 2015)

name: SKELLEY Christopher
Ambition: To win a medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. Away from sport he hopes to become a counsellor. (emergingproud.com, 20 Apr 2020)
Hero: British judoka Ian Johns, English rugby union player Jonny Wilkinson. (Athlete, 01 Apr 2016)
Philosophy: "The main limitation is in the mind and if you get over that you will be able to see the world and enjoy yourself." (paralympics.org.uk, 20 Nov 2018)
Award: In 2020 he received the Social Impact Award at UK Sport's PLx awards for his voluntary work for non-profit organisation Phoenix Enterprises during the COVID-19 pandemic. (uksport.gov.uk, 17 Nov 2020)
Injuries: In 2015 he dislocated his hip during training. He required surgery and was out of action for six weeks. (emergingproud.com, 20 Apr 2020)

name: SKINNER Zak
Ambition: To win a medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (britishathletics.org.uk, 19 Apr 2018)
Philosophy: "People want to go skiing or want to go on holiday or want to go to festivals whereas I can't do that. I've got a job to do and although you may want to be there at the time, nothing will beat the feeling of hopefully becoming like a European, world or Paralympic champion so it's worth the sacrifices." (paralympics.org.uk, 20 Aug 2018)

name: SKOMORAC Zerina
Debut: 2018 for Bosnia & Herzegovina, European Championship in Belgrade, Serbia (zenicainfo.ba, 29 Nov 2018)
Award: She was named the 2018 Female Para Athlete of the Year and the 2019 Para Athlete of the Year in Zenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina. (visoko.co.ba, 16 Jan 2020; tekma.ba, 14 Mar 2019)

name: SKOUBO Sofie Sejer
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (muskelsvindfonden.dk, 01 Aug 2018)
Philosophy: "Wheelchair rugby is a great sport because you are challenged both physically and tactically. And then it's a team sport where you are very active." (muskelsvindfonden.dk, 01 Aug 2018)

name: SKUJA Andrius
Debut: 2015 for Lithuania, Grand Prix in Berlin, Germany (Athlete, 06 Nov 2019)
Ambition: To win gold at the Paralympic Games. (Athlete, 21 Aug 2021)
Hero: Lithuanian discus thrower Virgilijus Alekna, Lithuanian powerlifter and strongman competitor Zydrunas Savickas. (Athlete, 06 Nov 2019)
Influence: His family, and coach Deimantas Jusys. (Athlete, 06 Nov 2019)
Philosophy: "Do the incredible, expect the unexpected." (Athlete, 23 Oct 2015)
Award: In 2018 and 2019 he was named among the Five Best Para Athletes of the Year by the Athletics Federation of Lithuania [LLAF]. (delfi.lt, 17 Jan 2020; lengvoji.lt, 19 Jan 2019)

name: SKYRPAN Amber
Debut: 2009 for Canada (Athlete, 15 Dec 2015)
Hero: Her father. (Athlete, 09 Mar 2011)

name: SLANOVA Viktoriia
Ambition: To win multiple gold medals at the Paralympic Games. (Athlete, 26 Oct 2019)
Hero: Russian Para sprinter and long jumper Gocha Khugaev, who is also her coach. (Athlete, 26 Oct 2019)
Influence: Coaches Gocha Khugaev and Boris Koroev. (Athlete, 26 Oct 2019)
Award: She has received the title of Master of Sport of International Class in the Russian Federation. (paralymp.ru, 19 Feb 2021)

name: SLIWINSKA Renata
Ambition: To set new world records in discus, shot put and javelin and to compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (fundusznataliipartyki.pl, 01 Jan 2017)
Hero: Polish footballer Robert Lewandowski. (paralympic.org.pl, 20 Nov 2019)
Award: She received the 2018 Honorary Athlete of the Year award in Lubuskie Voivodeship, Poland. (skwierzyna.pl, 03 Feb 2019)

name: SLOUP Matija
Ambition: To win a gold medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (dnevnik.hr, 03 Feb 2021)
Philosophy: "Difficult roads often lead to beautiful destinations." (Instagram profile, 01 Jan 2021)
Award: He was named 2018 Para Athlete of the Year by the Croatian Para Athletics Federation. (vecernji.hr, 29 Jan 2019)
Injuries: His performance at the 2016 Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro was hampered due to an injury he sustained one week before the Games. (paralympic.org, 24 Jan 2019)

name: SMALL Andrew
Debut: 2016 for Great Britain, European Championships in Grosseto, Italy (rio.paralympics.org.uk, 2016)
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (davidrandles.com, 15 Jun 2020)
Hero: British wheelchair racers Hannah Cockroft and David Weir. (athleticsweekly.com, 25 May 2017)
Philosophy: "It's a common misconception when people say, 'Hey, you, go for gold'. If you do get there just enjoy it. Just say you are going to do well, the best that you can do. Sometimes we can be too gold-centric focused. It's a shame. Why not just celebrate achievement for achievements? Enjoy it. Make the most of the experience. These things are finite. It's one life. We've got to live it as such." (davidrandles.com, 15 Jun 2020)
Injuries: He was troubled by a back injury between 2014 and 2015. (crewechronicle.co.uk, 12 Sep 2016, 22 Apr 2016)

name: SMARAGDI Styliani
Debut: 2009 for Greece, in Tunisia (Athlete, 23 Oct 2015)
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (Facebook page, 04 Mar 2017)
Hero: Serbian long jumper Ivana Spanovic. (Athlete, 20 Aug 2018)
Philosophy: "My hand is my strength to run fast and to become better." (Athlete, 23 Oct 2015)
Award: In 2014 she was named Female Athlete of the Year by the Greek Paralympic Committee. (paralympic.gr, 16 Dec 2014)
Injuries: In July 2020 she suffered a fractured fibula in her left leg during a competition and had to undergo surgery. (Facebook profile, 30 Jul 2020; Instagram profile, 30 Jul 2020)

name: SMEENK Austin
Debut: 2013 for Canada, World Championships in Lyon, France (Athlete, 11 Nov 2019)
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo. (Islandstats YouTube channel, 04 Feb 2021)
Hero: Canadian Para athlete Alister McQueen. (Athlete, 11 Nov 2019)
Influence: His first coach Ken Thom. (Athlete, 11 Nov 2019)
Philosophy: "Plan the work, work the plan. Trust the training." (Athlete, 11 Nov 2019)
Award: In 2014 he was presented with the Outstanding Male Track Events Performance of the Year Award by Athletics Ontario in Canada. (athleticsontario.ca, 01 Oct 2014)

name: SMETANINE David
Ambition: To win his 10th Paralympic medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (Athlete, 20 Mar 2019)
Hero: US sprinter and long jumper Carl Lewis. (Athlete, 20 Mar 2019)
Philosophy: "Never consider yourself defeated." (handisport.org, 10 Sep 2019)
Award: He received the 2018 Grand Prix Award from the Fair Play International Committee in Budapest, Hungary. (hu.ambafrance.org, 13 Sep 2019)

name: SMIRNOV Daniil
Ambition: To win gold at the Paralympic Games. (Athlete, 28 May 2019)
Hero: Russian mixed martial artist Fedor Emelianenko, US swimmer Michael Phelps, Russian swimmer Yulia Efimova. (Athlete, 28 May 2019)
Influence: His parents, and coach Denis Dorogaev. (Athlete, 28 May 2019)
Award: He has received the title of Master of Sport in the Russian Federation. (paralymp.ru, 08 Apr 2021)

name: SMIRNOV Kirill
Philosophy: "It's not important whether you were knocked down, it's important whether you got up again." (Instagram profile, 21 Apr 2021)
Award: He has received the title of Master of Sport of International Class in the Russian Federation. (paralymp.ru, 02 Apr 2021)

name: SMIRNOVA Irina
Ambition: To win gold at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (sportsdaily.ru, 20 Aug 2018)
Award: In 2018 she received the title of Honoured Master of Sport in the Russian Federation. (paralymp.ru, 19 Oct 2018)

name: SMITH Ali
Philosophy: "I don't worry about the world ending, it's ended for me a few times but began again in the morning." (Instagram profile, 08 Sep 2019)

name: SMITH Brodie
Ambition: To win gold at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (Athlete, 20 Aug 2021)
Hero: Australian goalball player Meica Horsburgh. (Athlete, 20 Aug 2021)
Philosophy: "As long as you try your best, you're already a winner." (Athlete, 20 Aug 2021)
Award: She won the Leading Goal Scorer Award at the 2017 World Youth Championships in Budapest, Hungary. (Save Sight Institute YouTube channel, 05 Jul 2019)

name: SMITH David
Hero: His grandfather. (Athlete, 22 Aug 2021)
Philosophy: "Play with freedom." (Athlete, 22 Aug 2021)
Award: He was named a Member of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire [MBE] in the 2017 New Year's Honours list, for services to boccia. (southwales-eveningpost.co.uk, 05 Jan 2017)

name: SMITH Elizabeth
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (myswimpro.com, 31 Mar 2020)
Hero: Spanish Para swimmer Sarai Gascon Moreno. (teamusa.org, 08 Jun 2017)
Influence: Her parents, her siblings [she is one of eight], and coach Ian Crocker. (myswimpro.com, 31 Mar 2020)
Philosophy: "Inclusion to me is like a swim meet. I show up on race day with my meticulously rehearsed race plan, a lane, and a goal. My competitors share the same goal - to be faster than they were yesterday. They don't know, care, or notice that I have a disability. I am my ability. All I need is the opportunity to see how fast I can go." (Instagram profile, 09 Mar 2021)

name: SMITH Hallie
Ambition: To win a medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. Outside of sport she would like to become a nurse. (Facebook page, 14 Jun 2019; Athlete, 25 Aug 2021)
Hero: US wheelchair racer Tatyana McFadden. (usrowing.org, 16 Feb 2018)
Philosophy: "Don't quit. Suffer now and live the rest of your life as a champion." [Muhammad Ali] (Athlete, 25 Aug 2021)

name: SMITH Jack
Debut: 2020 for Great Britain, in Leicester, Great Britain (gbwr.org.uk, 06 Feb 2020)

name: SMITH Johnboy
Debut: 2014 for Great Britain, Grand Prix in Berlin, Germany (britishathletics.org.uk, 23 Jun 2014)
Ambition: To win gold in the marathon at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (bbc.co.uk, 25 Apr 2019)
Philosophy: "My motivation is that you can have the worst news in the world, but there is life after disability and tragedy." (bbc.co.uk, 25 Apr 2019)
Injuries: He dislocated his shoulder during the March 2021 Wheelchair Marathon at the Thruxton Motorsport Centre in England and was unable to complete the race. He was cleared to return to sport in early June 2021 and raced 10 days later. (duluthnewstribune.com, 19 Jun 2021; thruxtonracing.co.uk, 29 Mar 2021)

name: SMITH Leanne
Philosophy: "Don't focus on your disabilities. Instead, focus on what you are still able to do. If you can change your attitude and are willing to put in the time and the work, so much is possible." (patients.aan.com, 01 Feb 2014)

name: SMITH Natalie
Debut: 2011 for Australia, in London, Great Britain (paralympic.org.au, 14 Nov 2011)
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (Facebook page, 26 Sep 2018)
Philosophy: "Instead of looking at the hundred-thousand reasons to quit, look at the thousand reasons not to give up." (nataliesmith.com.au, 21 May 2017)
Award: In 2012, 2013 and 2016 she was named Para Shooter of the Year by Shooting Australia. She also received the 2015 Elite Para Athlete of the Year award from Shooting Australia. (shootingaustralia.org, 2018)
Injuries: In 2019 she sustained a shoulder injury while visiting Hanover, Germany. (Facebook page, 24 Aug 2019)

name: SMITH Shayne
Philosophy: "It's not the cards you're dealt, it's the hand you play." (lakeshore.org, 25 Aug 2016)
Award: He was flag bearer for Team Ontario at the opening ceremony of the 2011 Canada Winter Games in Halifax, Nova Scotia. (lakeshore.org, 25 Aug 2016)

name: SMRCKA Miroslav
Debut: 2015 for Czech Republic (Athlete, 05 Dec 2017)
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (ustecky.denik.cz, 05 Oct 2016)
Hero: US swimmer Bradley Snyder. (Athlete, 05 Dec 2017)
Award: In 2019 he was named Best Impaired Athlete in the Usti nad Labem region of the Czech Republic. (litomericky.denik.cz, 16 Sep 2020)

name: SMYRNOV Viktor
Debut: 2002 for Ukraine, World Championships in Mar del Plata, Argentina (Athlete, 20 Jul 2014)
Ambition: To win a medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (Athlete, 08 Mar 2020)
Award: In recognition of his performance at the 2016 Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, he received the Order for Merit [third class] in Ukraine. (president.gov.ua, 04 Oct 2016)

name: SMYTH Jason
Debut: 2006 for Ireland, European Championships in Espoo, Finland (paralympic.org, 05 Mar 2020; Athlete, 20 Dec 2010)
Ambition: To win a gold medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo, and to compete at the 2024 Paralympic Games in Paris. (insidethegames.biz, 17 Feb 2021; irishmirror.ie, 16 Feb 2021)
Hero: English footballer Steven Gerrard, English physicist Stephen Hawking. (paralympic.org, 15 Feb 2015)
Philosophy: "Believe in yourself and what you can achieve. I didn't grow in any different circumstance than anybody else, but what I did do was put myself in the best possible environment to succeed. If you believe in yourself there is no limit to where you can actually go." (bbc.com, 28 Jul 2020)
Award: In 2009 he received an honorary doctorate from Queen's University Belfast in Northern Ireland. (paralympic.org, 05 Mar 2020)
Injuries: He sustained an injury just below one of his knees in 2013. The injury caused him persistent pain and he eventually underwent surgery in 2015. (paralympic.org, 07 Jun 2019)

name: SNIKUS Rihards
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (skaties.lv, 18 Jul 2018)
Hero: Latvian ice hockey player Sandis Ozolins. (Athlete, 18 Sep 2016)
Philosophy: "Any competition is a great challenge. I never know what to expect, but always hope for the best. But both losses and victories make me try even harder. Losses don't make me want to give up; they make me even stronger and more ambitious." (paralympic.org, 21 Jun 2019)
Award: In January 2013 he was named Paralympic Rider of the Year at a ceremony in Latvia. (delfi.lv, 22 Jan 2013)

name: SOARES da SILVA CALADO Evani
Award: She was named the 2016 Para Boccia Athlete of the Year by the Brazilian Paralympic Committee [CPB]. (paralympic.org, 02 Dec 2016)

name: SOARES da SILVA Rayane
Ambition: To win a gold medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (paralympic.org, 07 Nov 2019)
Award: In 2017 and 2018 she was named Best Para Athlete at the Brasilia Sports Awards in Brazil. (agenciabrasilia.df.gov.br, 17 Dec 2018; sistemafibra.org.br, 18 Apr 2018)

name: SOARES de OLIVEIRA Ana Karolina
Hero: Brazilian swimmer Etiene Medeiros. (Instagram profile, 08 Jun 2021)

name: SOCHAL Maciej
Debut: 2004 for Poland (Athlete, 17 Jul 2017)
Ambition: To win a medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (tvp.pl, 23 Jan 2021)
Hero: Polish shot putter Tomasz Majewski. (Athlete, 17 Jul 2017)
Philosophy: "Never give up." (MrMichalPol YouTube channel, 22 Aug 2018)
Award: In 2016 he was presented with the Gold Cross of Merit in Poland. (prezydent.pl, 05 Oct 2016)
Injuries: His training was disrupted ahead of the 2017 World Championships due to injuries to his shoulder and groin. He went on to win a silver medal in the F32 club throw at the event in London, England. (paralympic.org, 23 Jul 2018; gk24.pl, 22 Jul 2017)

name: SODARIO TORQUATO Nathan Cesar
Debut: 2017 for Brazil, World Championships in London, Great Britain (jornalgazetadolitoral.com.br, 15 Oct 2017)
Ambition: To win gold at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (agenciabrasil.ebc.org.br, 18 Jan 2021)
Influence: Coach Rodney Saraiva and his family. (globoplay.globo.com, 08 Apr 2021)
Award: He was named Best Male Para Taekwondoka of the Americas by taekwondo news website Mundo Taekwondo in 2020. (agenciabrasil.ebc.org.br, 18 Jan 2021)

name: SOERLIE-ROGNE Heidi Kristin
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (ffo.no, 27 Nov 2020)
Philosophy: "Always think possibilities and not limitations." (rb.no, 18 Jul 2014)

name: SOKOLOV Saska
Ambition: To win a medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (espreso.rs, 25 Oct 2019)
Hero: Estonian javelin thrower Magnus Kirt. (Athlete, 05 Nov 2019)
Philosophy: "If you really want something and love it, then everything is possible. Most important is strong will, desire, and perseverance. Never give up." (iserbia.rs, 06 Feb 2017)
Injuries: She had a back injury when she competed at the 2019 World Championships in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. (plusonline.rs, 11 Nov 2019)

name: SOKULSKII Sergei
Ambition: To win gold at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (Athlete, 25 Oct 2019)
Hero: Russian mixed martial arts fighters Khabib Nurmagomedov and Fedor Emelianenko. (Athlete, 25 Oct 2019)
Award: In 2020 he received the title of Master of Sport of International Class in the Russian Federation. (minsport.gov.ru, 30 Apr 2020)

name: SOLBERG Fredrik
Debut: 2017 for Norway (Athlete, 15 Aug 2018)
Ambition: To win a medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (idrettsforbundet.no, 20 May 2020; 18 Mar 2019)
Hero: Norwegian cross-country skier Petter Northug. (Athlete, 15 Aug 2018)
Philosophy: "During every training session there is something new to learn or you find new things to think about. You always have the potential to improve and there is always something to aim for." (reavisa.no, 07 Dec 2017)
Award: In 2020 he received the Jysk scholarship in recognition of his achievements in the sport. (idrettsforbundet.no, 20 May 2020)
Injuries: He sustained a shoulder injury in 2016. (reavisa.no, 07 Dec 2017)

name: SOLDE Typhaine
Debut: 2019 for France (handisport.org, 01 Nov 2019)
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo and the 2024 Paralympic Games in Paris, and to win a Paralympic medal. (ouest-france.fr, 03 Nov 2019; byathlete.com, 09 Apr 2020; futursport.org, 02 May 2020)
Hero: French Para athlete Marie-Amelie Le Fur. (futursport.org, 02 May 2020)
Philosophy: "Focus on the path you have to go on, and don't regret what you've been through. All the experiences and scars have made you the person you are." (france3-regions.francetvinfo.fr, 08 Mar 2021)

name: SOLHIPOURAVANJI Seyedhamed
Debut: 2008 for Iran (Athlete, 15 Jul 2019)
Ambition: To win a medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo, and to win gold medals at the world championships and the Asian Para Games. (irisfd.ir, 5 Apr 2021; Athlete, 22 Aug 2021)
Hero: Iranian Para powerlifter Siamand Rahman. (Athlete, 22 Aug 2021)
Influence: His parents, and Iranian Para powerlifters Kazem Rajabi Golojeh and Siamand Rahman. (Athlete, 15 Jul 2019, 22 Aug 2021; irisfd.ir, 23 Oct 2018)
Philosophy: "Every athlete's medal is the result of the effort of a whole team." (irisfd.ir, 23 Oct 2018)

name: SOLODUKHINA Alina
Debut: 2018 for Kazakhstan (Athlete, 11 Jul 2019)
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (Instagram profile, 12 Aug 2021)
Hero: Kazakhstani weightlifter Ilya Ilyin, Russian footballer Artem Dzyuba. (Athlete, 11 Jul 2019)
Philosophy: "Train the body, take care of the soul." (Instagram profile, 12 Aug 2021)
Award: She has received the title of Master of Sport of International Class in Kazakhstan. (Athlete, 22 Feb 2019)

name: SOLOVEVA Anastasiia
Debut: 2015 for Russia, World Championships in Doha, Qatar (Athlete, 04 Sep 2016)
Ambition: To win gold at the Paralympic Games. (Athlete, 23 Oct 2019)
Hero: Russian high jumper Mariya Lasitskene. (Athlete, 23 Oct 2019)
Philosophy: "What does not kill us, makes us stronger." (ngzt.ru, 30 Aug 2016)
Award: She received the 2019 Overcoming Award for Best Female Para Athlete of the Year in the Ulyanovsk region of the Russian Federation. (73online.ru, 24 Dec 2019)

name: SOLOVEY Dmytro
Debut: 2010 for Ukraine, World Championships in Antalya, Turkey (Athlete, 01 Apr 2016)
Ambition: To win a gold medal at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (24tv.ua, 01 Jan 2017)
Philosophy: "Sport for me is a start in life." (24tv.ua, 01 Jan 2017)
Award: In recognition of his achievements at the 2012 and 2016 Paralympic Games, he received the Orders for Merits [third and second classes] in Ukraine. (president.gov.ua, 04 Oct 2016; zakon.rada.gov.ua, 17 Sep 2012)

name: SOLOVIOVA Lidiia
Debut: 1999 for Ukraine, European Championships (fakty.ua, 25 Sep 2004)
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (Athlete, 26 May 2019)

Philosophy: "I have been asked what motivates me, and it is quite a hard question to answer. It has changed over the years. It used to be fear of being a burden to the world, and while that's diminished it's still a bit there. I think now there are two main motivations. One. I love running, I love sport, I love training, I love competing. Just doing the sport is enough motivation, but it's not the only reason. Two. I have a desire to make a positive impact on the world, one that a younger version of me would appreciate. I want to show that we can all be better than what other people's imaginations allow." (Instagram profile, 01 Feb 2020)

Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo, and to become president of the Italian Olympic Committee [CONI]. (Twitter profile, 04 Jan 2021; news.johncabot.edu, 08 Dec 2018)
Influence: Italian fencer Valentina Vezzali, and her family. (Athlete, 31 Jul 2016; bebevio.com, 28 Aug 2020)
Philosophy: "I realised that I was enjoying wheelchair fencing much more than standing fencing. In standing fencing if you are afraid you can escape to the bottom of the platform, while sitting instead you are blocked there. You can not escape. You can't be afraid." (bebevio.com, 28 Aug 2020)
Award: She was named Sportsperson of the Year With a Disability at the 2017 Laureus Awards. (bbc.co.uk, 14 Feb 2017)

name: VITELARU Ana Maria
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (Instagram profile, 20 Jul 2021)
Philosophy: "Nothing happens for no reason. Suffering changes us and makes us understand who we are. It puts us at a crossroads and we have to choose white or black. You can become more sensitive, grow through the trauma suffered and appreciate what you have much more. Or you can sit and say the world owes me everything after what has happened to me, and do nothing for yourself. Sport helps a lot. It removes the limitations." (ilmessaggero.it, 14 Jul 2019)

name: VONGSA Watcharaphon
Ambition: To win individual and team gold at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (Paralympic Games Facebook page, 02 Aug 2020)

name: VORIS Richard
Debut: 2014 for Australia (paralympic.org.au, 01 Sep 2020)
Ambition: To win a gold medal at the Paralympic Games. (paralympic.org.au, 01 Sep 2020)
Philosophy: "Wheelchair rugby has changed my life in a lot of ways. It's gotten me from thinking I'm in a wheelchair and things are pretty tough, to me not caring about that at all. I've met so many cool people, new friends who I just love. It's awesome getting out and being active and travelling the world to play sport - it's a pretty good life. To be honest, if I could break my neck, I'd break it again, because I'm in such a good place." (abc.net.au, 10 Feb 2019)
Injuries: In 2018 he missed the world championships in Sydney, NSW, Australia, due to a flare-up of autoimmune condition myasthenia gravis. (paralympic.org.au, 01 Sep 2020)

name: WEGGEMANN Mallory
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (malloryweggemannusa.com, 24 Apr 2019)
Philosophy: "Sport has been a fundamental part of my identity since I was a child, but in 2008 following my paralysis, it brought me back to life. My family and I were exposed to the Paralympic movement for the first time, and learned about adaptive sport. Since, I have seen the power that sport has to transcend the field of play and change perception of disability not only in our society, but for oneself. " (Facebook page, 11 Mar 2021)
Award: In 2011 she won the ESPY award for Best Female Athlete with a Disability from sports broadcaster ESPN. (CNN, 12 Aug 2011)

name: WHEELER Joshua

It takes you from going through an accident and being in a wheelchair to having friends who are also doing the same. You can learn so many things about how to make your life better through the sport." (tucsonlocalmedia.com, 05 Feb 2020)

Philosophy: "A bird's trust isn't in the branch it sits on, but in its own wings to fly." (Athlete, 11 Dec 2014)
Award: She was named Member of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire [MBE] in the 2015 Queen's Birthday Honours list. (Facebook page, 10 Jul 2020; bbc.co.uk, 06 Nov 2015)

name: ZYLKA Krzysztof
Debut: 2006 for Poland, in Wladyslawowo, Poland (Athlete, 18 May 2016)
Ambition: To compete at the 2020 Paralympic Games in Tokyo. (leliwa.pl, 24 Oct 2019)
Hero: US basketball player Michael Jordan, Polish table tennis player Andrzej Grubba. (Athlete, 18 May 2016; pttp.org.pl, 2016)
Injuries: On his second day after arriving at the 2016 Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, he fell from his wheelchair and suffered a broken tibia. He was initially unaware of the severity of the injury due to the numbness in his legs caused by his impairment. After experiencing shortness of breath following the opening ceremony of the Games, he was also diagnosed with an embolism. The embolism was successfully treated and he was able to compete in Rio de Janeiro, but he required oxygen after his first match. (fakt.pl, 22 Sep 2016)
